sect1.title: CASE 35
sect1.para: The patient was a female in her 50s who presented to the wound clinic with an ulcer on the bottom of her left foot. She had a 15-year history of diabetes, and her most recent blood sugar level, assessed the day previously, was 245 mg/dl. Five years ago she had a stroke, and she had been unable to work since then. She denied alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drug use.

listitem.para: 1. How well-controlled was this patient’s diabetes?

2. People who are treated at a wound clinic typically have chronic infections. Explain why this patient likely had an infected ulcer on the bottom of the foot. What is the prognosis for these individuals?

sect1.para: The patient’s daughter reported that the foot was red, swollen, and smelled “horribly.”

listitem.para: 3. Wounds with a horrible smell are frequently associated with what large group of microorganisms?

sect1.para: The patient denied fever and chills but reported vomiting and nausea that morning. She lived alone and had eight cats until recently, when her daughter took seven of the cats away when the patient was admitted to the hospital. The patient denied the cats licking her wound but admitted that the cats frequently bite and scratch her hands and arms.

listitem.para: 4. What organisms are typically associated with diabetic foot infections? How might the history of cat bites and scratches change your differential of organisms that could be causing the individual’s infection?

sect1.para: On physical examination, the patient’s vital signs were unremarkable. She was found to have a 2- by 2-cm wound on the plantar surface of the left foot with moderate serous drainage. Purulent drainage was not observed. She had a well-circumscribed area of erythema and heat on her left lower leg and foot.

listitem.para: 5. What type of infection would give the signs that were seen in this patient?

sect1.para: A radiograph of the foot was consistent with a soft tissue infection with possible osteomyelitis. On admission, her laboratory findings were significant for a white blood cell count of 14,800/μl and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 140 mm/hour.

listitem.para: 6. How do you interpret these two significant laboratory findings?

sect1.para: On admission, the patient had an incision and drainage of her foot ulcer. Three tissue biopsies and blood cultures were obtained and cultured in the microbiology laboratory. After the cultures were resulted, she was begun on intravenous piperacillin/tazobactam.

listitem.para: 7. What was the role of the tissue biopsies and blood cultures in determining if the patient had osteomyelitis?

sect1.para: A direct Gram stain is seen in Fig. 35.1.

listitem.para: 8. How do you interpret the Gram stain? Would it be appropriate to de-escalate her antimicrobial therapy based on the Gram stain findings?

sect1.para: The organism grew from three separate tissue samples from her foot (Fig. 35.2). The organism is oxidase positive. The triple sugar iron (TSI) reaction is acid/acid, and the organism is spot indole positive.

listitem.para: 9. What organism was likely recovered from her foot, based on the colony morphology, the media on which the organism grew, and the laboratory tests that were done? Was the antimicrobial an appropriate choice for infection with this organism? Explain your answer.

sect1.para: After 5 days, the patient’s blood cultures were reported as negative. She was discharged to a rehabilitation facility after a 12-day hospital course to complete a 14-day antibiotic treatment, to monitor her diabetes management, and for wound care.

Given the clinical setting, the organism causing this patient’s infection was not surprising, but the clinical setting of this case was unusual. Typically, patients with infections with this organism present in the emergency department (ED). It is estimated that there are more than 300,000 ED visits each year for treatment of bite wounds, many of which are infected(1).

listitem.para: 10. Besides cats, bites from what two other mammalian species are frequent sources of infection in patients cared for at EDs in the United States? What organisms are associated with potentially serious infections such as osteomyelitis and sepsis in these two mammals?

11. What infection acquired from mammalian bites is a leading cause of death globally? Where do these deaths primarily occur? What strategies can protect travelers to those regions of the world? What are the top four mammalian species that are infected with this human pathogen in the United States? What domestic animal is most likely to be infected in the United States? Why?

sect1.para: 1. The target blood sugar for a preprandial diabetic patient is 80 to 130 mg/dl (2). Her glucose level was twice that, suggesting that her blood sugar levels were not well controlled. Poorly controlled diabetes is associated with neuropathy, peripheral vascular disease, renal failure, cardiac disease, and stroke.

2. The combination of peripheral vascular disease and neuropathy, a common finding in individuals with poorly controlled diabetes, can result in chronic ulcer formation (3). Peripheral vascular disease can result in localized ischemia. The resulting poor tissue perfusion can lead to tissue necrosis and ulcer formation. Individuals with peripheral neuropathy may not notice traumatic injury to the foot because of the lack of sensation. Because the injury is unnoticed, proper wound care such as cleansing and covering the wound may not occur, increasing the likelihood of developing an infection. The immune response may also be delayed because of poor peripheral perfusion, leading to chronic infection.

Chronic foot infections are a serious complication of diabetes and are a common reason for individuals with diabetes to visit the ED or be admitted to the hospital(4). It is estimated that as many as half of diabetic foot ulcers become infected. As many as 20% of patients with moderate to severe chronic foot infections will require some type of amputation. Five-year mortality in these individuals exceeds 70%.

3. As discussed in question 2, this individual had significant peripheral vascular disease, which can result in chronic foot infections. One of the characteristics of peripheral vascular disease is foot ulcers. When infected, as occurred in this patient, the center of the ulcer is necrotic (4). Necrotic tissue is often malodorous. However, the daughter’s report that the foot smelled “horribly” suggests that infection with a mixture of anaerobic and aerobic bacteria should be considered. Anaerobes produce short, branched-chained fatty acids, which are particularly malodorous. If clinicians find the wound particularly malodorous, they should consider empiric antimicrobials that are effective against anaerobes.

4. The organisms most commonly associated with diabetic foot infections are Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA); beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococci); other staphylococci; and Gram-negative bacilli including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Proteus spp. Anaerobic bacteria may also be recovered (5). If the patient has received prior antimicrobial treatment for a diabetic foot infection, the concern for the presence of multidrug-resistant organisms such as MRSA or extended-spectrum beta-lactamase or carbapenemase-producing Gram-negative bacilli should be increased. There is an emerging school of thought that these infections are frequently due to a mixture of bacteria growing as a mixed-organism biofilm (6). A biofilm mode of growth is often refractory to antimicrobial therapy. Due to this, wound debridement is central to infection resolution. Unfortunately, the combination of antimicrobial therapy and wound debridement in the setting of severe peripheral vascular disease may eventually result in amputation because antimicrobials do not penetrate the site of infection, and debridement may only slow but not cure the infection.

This microbial differential diagnosis of this case was narrowed by the observation that this woman was frequently scratched and bitten by pet cats. The most common cause of infection following cat bites is Pasteurella multocida, a Gram-negative bacillus frequently found as a predominant member of the oral microbiota in feline animals (7). Because cats have sharp, slender teeth, which allow them to introduce these organisms into deep tissue, the organism can cause severe damage to tendons, ligaments, and bone and is associated with tenosynovitis, septic arthritis, and osteomyelitis (1). The etiologic agent of cat scratch disease (i. e.,Bartonella henselae) would also need to be considered, although the clinical presentation would be significantly different.

5. The presentation seen here is consistent with cellulitis, which is inflammation (red, warm to the touch) of skin and soft tissue. The most common etiologies of cellulitis are S. aureus, including MRSA and group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) (8). However, P. multocida is the most common cellulitis etiology following a cat bite or scratch (7).

6. The radiology report suggests that the patient may have osteomyelitis. A plain film is not the optimum imaging study for the detection of osteomyelitis. Rather, magnetic resonance imaging is superior for the detection of osteomyelitis in individuals with diabetic foot ulcers (5). An ESR level of >100 mm/hour is suggestive of an osteomyelitis diagnosis, as is the patient’s elevated white cell count (9).

7. Because of a high index of suspicion for osteomyelitis based on imaging and a high white blood cell count and ESR, determining the etiology of her infection would inform the antimicrobial therapy she would receive. The evidence for the recommended treatment for osteomyelitis secondary to chronic diabetic foot infection is very limited. The recommended length of therapy can be anywhere from 1 week to 3 months, depending on the severity and etiology of the infection (5). Thus, selecting the appropriate antimicrobial is essential to limit the length of treatment to avoid complications associated with long-term antimicrobial therapy, such as Clostridioides difficile infection.

The appropriate specimen for determining the etiology of an individual infection is a tissue biopsy(10). Swabs of the wound surface are insensitive and nonspecific, often positive for a mixture of bacteria that are part of the skin microbiota colonizing the ulcer surface. The organism causing the infection will be in deep tissue on the ulcer’s edge. Biopsy in this ulcer region will have the highest and most specific diagnostic yield. Blood cultures are highly specific as a diagnostic tool for osteomyelitis but have a very low sensitivity of <20% (11). The low sensitivity is likely due to patients receiving antimicrobials prior to culture.

8. When positive, a Gram stain from a tissue biopsy can be useful in determining the infection's etiology. The Gram stain shows pleiomorphic, Gram-negative bacilli and polymorphonuclear cells. The most common pleiomorphic, Gram-negative bacilli encountered in clinical specimens are members of the genera Haemophilus and Moraxella. However, these two genera are typically associated with respiratory tract infections rather than wounds. The history of the patient having multiple cats that bit and scratched her alerted the clinician to the fact that these traumatic events might have been the source of her infection. Since P. multocida is a pleiomorphic, Gram-negative bacillus and the most common cause of infections following cat bites and scratches, it was the most likely cause of her infection. Since some beta-lactamase-producing, anaerobic, Gram-negative rods should also be considered but were much less likely, the continuation of the beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor was prudent, especially since P. multocida is susceptible to that drug combination.

9. P. multocidais an oxidase-positive, pleiomorphic, Gram-negative bacillus that grows on sheep blood and chocolate agars but not Mac Conkey agar. The organism ferments glucose and sucrose, so it will give an acid/acid reaction on a TSI slant. The organism is also spot indole positive. Based on these laboratory tests, the organism was identified as P. multocida. Large hospitals, academic medical centers, and commercial reference laboratories likely use matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectroscopy to identify Pasteurella because it is highly accurate (12). Laboratories in smaller hospitals especially in middle- and low-income countries will use conventional approaches described above.

P. multocida is typically susceptible to all beta-lactam drugs active against Gram-negative organisms. The IDSA (Infectious Diseases Society of America) recommends the use of beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitors for treatment of chronic foot infections, so the physician was following those guidelines (5). An antimicrobial stewardship team might choose to de-escalate to a narrower antimicrobial treatment to reduce the risk of C. difficile infection.

10. Dog bites are responsible for approximately 80 to 90% of bite wound ED visits (1). These bites occur primarily in males. Cat bites, as seen in this case, are responsible for 5 to 15% of bite wound ED visits. These are most likely to occur in adult females. Humans are responsible for approximately 2 to 3% of bite wound ED visits. There are two common types of human bite wound injuries (1). One is closed-hand injuries in which a person’s hand is injured when striking someone in the mouth. This occurs primarily in adult males. Human bite wounds may also occur when children bite fingers or soft tissues of others.

The most common pathogens in dog bites are Pasteurella canis and P. multocida (7). An organism associated with sepsis following dog bites is Capnocytophaga canimorsus, a fastidious, slow-growing, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative bacillus that requires increased CO2 for growth (13). Sepsis due to C. canimorsus occurs primarily in individuals who have had a splenectomy or have cirrhosis of the liver. The mortality associated with this infection is 25%.

Most bite wound infections following human bites are secondary to closed-fist injuries.Eikenella corrodens is a common pathogen found in osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and tenosynovitis secondary to human bites (1). It is a fastidious, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative bacillus that has a characteristic bleach odor with colonies that pit the agar.
HIV, hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus have all been shown to be transmitted by human bites (1, 7).

11. The rabies virus is responsible for an estimated 60,000 deaths a year globally, primarily in Africa and Asia, with half the deaths occurring in children (14). It is estimated that 20,000 rabies deaths occur in India alone. Over 99% of human rabies is transmitted from dogs in low- and middle-income countries. People such as missionaries and aid and health care workers who will be spending extended periods of time in rural areas of Africa and Asia, where dogs may roam more freely, should consider being vaccinated against rabies. If not vaccinated, they should have a contingency plan of how to receive postrabies prophylaxis within a week if bitten by dogs, bats, raccoons, or other canines (jackals, foxes, wolves). In general, they should avoid all contact with free-roaming dogs (14).

In the United States and most other industrialized nations, rabies has essentially been eliminated from dogs by an aggressive vaccination program. No such program exists for cats, although 27 U. S. states do require cats to be vaccinated. As a result, cats are four times more likely to be infected(15)by rabies compared to dogs. In suburban and rural areas of the United States, people may come in contact with rabid animals, which accounts for over 90% of the U. S. animal rabies cases. The virus is found most frequently in bats, raccoons, skunks, and foxes. There are approximately one to three human rabies cases in the United States annually. A recent human case reported by the CDC occurred following extensive bat exposure in the patient’s home(16).

listitem.para: Poorly controlled diabetes can result in chronic wound infections of the feet. Both peripheral neuropathy and vascular disease secondary to diabetes contribute to chronic wound development.
Characteristics of chronic foot infections include redness, warmth, swelling, tenderness, and pain.
Important complications of chronic foot infection in diabetes include osteomyelitis and amputation. Amputation is associated with a 5-year mortality of 70%.

The most common pathogens in chronic wound infections are S. aureus, including methicillin-resistant S. aureus; beta-hemolytic streptococci, including both S. pyogenes and S. agalactiae; and P. aeruginosa, E. coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, especially multidrug-resistant strains, and selected anaerobes.

In this case, an unusual organism was detected in the tissue biopsy of the wound,P. multocida. This organism, a fastidious, facultative Gram-negative bacillus, is most commonly associated with wound infections following cat bites and scratches. The patient’s history revealed that she had been bitten and scratched on multiple occasions by her cats.

Infections following mammalian bites are a common reason for individuals to be cared for in the ED. Infections following dog bites are most common, followed by cat bites and then human bites. Important pathogens include P. multocida from cats, Pasteurella species and C. canimorsus from dogs, and E. corrodens from humans. HIV and hepatitis B and C viruses can also be transmitted by human bites.

Rabies virus can be obtained from bites of a variety of mammals infected with this virus. Globally, dog bites are the most common source of human rabies. Vaccination of dogs has controlled human rabies in much of the industrialized world, but the disease is still common in parts of Africa and Asia. In the United States, cats, which are not required to be vaccinated against rabies in 23 states, are the domestic animal most likely to become infected. Over 90% of U. S. animal rabies is found in wildlife, with the virus being most common in bats, raccoons, skunks, and foxes. Human rabies is rare in the United States.
